TRUE.

Researchers at the University of Washington (UW) have developed a shape-changing smart speaker system that allows users to mute specific areas within a room[1][2][3]. The system uses a swarm of self-deploying mobile microphones to divide a room into distinct "speech zones," track the location of individual speakers, and selectively manage audio capture[4][5].

## System Design and Functionality

The technology, referred to as a robotic "acoustic swarm," utilizes a fleet of small, inch-in-diameter robots that function as mobile microphones[7]. These robots, likened to a "fleet of Roombas," automatically deploy from a central charging station and position themselves for optimal sound differentiation[2][1]. The prototype consists of seven such robots that disperse across a surface, using high-frequency sound to navigate and avoid obstacles[7][8].

By spreading out, the microphones maximize the distance between each other, which enhances the system's ability to locate and differentiate speakers[7]. This automated deployment allows the system to be moved between environments and set itself up without manual configuration[1].

## Core Technology and Performance

The system's capabilities are driven by deep-learning algorithms developed by the UW team[2][9]. These neural networks analyze the time-delayed signals of a person's voice arriving at the different microphones[1]. As explained by co-lead author Tuochao Chen, a voice will arrive first at the microphone closest to the speaker, and this time difference is used to separate what each person is saying and track their position[1][11].

This allows the system to separate simultaneous conversations and isolate individual voices, even when speakers are adjacent and have similar voice timbres[3][2].

*   **Accuracy**: In tests conducted in various environments with three to five speakers, the system could distinguish between different voices within 1.6 feet (50 centimeters) of each other 90% of the time[7].
*   **Speed**: The system processes three seconds of audio in an average of 1.82 seconds, which is fast enough for live streaming applications, though slightly too slow for real-time communications like video calls[7].

## Applications and Future Directions

A primary application of the technology is enhanced privacy and audio control[9]. According to co-lead author Malek Itani, a UW doctoral student, a user could command the system to create a "mute zone" or a "sound bubble" where audio is not recorded[7][12]. For instance, a user could say, "Don’t record anything around my desk," and the system would create a three-foot bubble in which nothing is recorded[4][13]. This could also be used to keep a private conversation from being recorded while another conversation nearby is being captured[1].

Other potential uses include:
*   **Smart Homes**: Deploying acoustic swarms to better differentiate commands given to smart speakers. For example, creating an "active zone" on a couch where only people sitting there can vocally control a TV[15].
*   **Conference Rooms**: Using the system in place of a central microphone to allow for better control and clarity of in-room audio[16][11].

The research team plans to develop microphone robots that can move around entire rooms, not just on tables, and is also investigating whether the speakers can emit sound to create real-world active zones where people in different parts of a room can hear different audio.

This research is distinct from other UW audio projects like "Target Speech Hearing" and "semantic hearing," which focus on AI-powered headphones that allow a wearer to filter or select specific sounds in their environment[18][19].
